titleStmt.title: Variants of This is the feature-file for apophonic passive
titleStmt.author: Veronika Engler

sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for apophonic passive (yes – no – only in pfv).

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found
updating references to Zotero IDs via update-bibl-refs.xsl

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Pickett (2005:245) notes that "None of the Lebanese tribes demonstrated any examples of the so called 'internal passive'. Rather, in every case the passive is formed by the prefix of in-".

Pickett (2005:245) notes that "None of the Lebanese tribes demonstrated any examples of the so called 'internal passive'. Rather, in every case the passive is formed by the prefix of in-".
vestigial forms: xilig "to be created", hilik "to be tired"
Authors write: we can note that no examples of internal passive are recorded in the texts, nor could be elicited, the informant changing instead to a form 7 verb.

div.wib:featureValueObservation: Autor writes: In AZ, only two vestiges of the internal passive were preserved, having GOD as their subject, namely the verbs rizig, yarzag "to make a living, to be blessed wit", and xulug, yuxlug "to be born, be created", which coexist alongside their transitive cunterparts. Because of the disappearance of the passive, some derived forms are used to express passive occurrences, primarly forms VII and VIII.

wib:featureValueObservation.note: example given just in IPFV
This type of passive is extremely rare.

The internal passive occurs commonly in a few fixed phrases, e.g. wāḥid yigāl lih ‘someone called…’, wlidt (A)/xlukt (B villages) ‘I was born’; otherwise sporadically e.g. alḥīn ruwyat, tinǧaḥ ‘now it [crop] has been watered, it'll grow’ (B village); lēn yinzaf u yisikk illōḥ ‘when it has been baled out and the timbers have tightened’ (A) (Holes 2007).

The internal passive occurs commonly in a few fixed phrases, e.g. wāḥid yigāl lih ‘someone called…’, wlidt (A)/xlukt (B villages) ‘I was born’; otherwise sporadically e.g. alḥīn ruwyat, tinǧaḥ ‘now it [crop] has been watered, it'll grow’ (B village); lēn yinzaf u yisikk illōḥ ‘when it has been baled out and the timbers have tightened’ (A) (Holes 2007).
The apophonic passive occurs more frequently in the village dialects of the Baḥārna than in the urban varieties or in the ʕArab variety.

The internal passive occurs in normal speech only in a few fixed phrases, and usually in the imperfect, e.g. wāḥid yigāl lih ‘someone called…’, wlidt ‘I was born’, but more commonly in proverbs, e.g. iḏa ṭigg ilxašim, ihmalat ilʿēn ‘if the nose is struck, the eye weeps’(Holes 2007).
The patterns for the apophonic passive are fiʕil and yifʕal.
The apophonic passive only occurs in some fixed expressions, e.g. tislam īdēkum 'May your hands be blessed'.
No information is available about the imperfective form of the passive.
"extremely rare"
A handful of forms can be found: yūṣäb 'it will be found', also interesting waqela 'maybe' from CA waqīl possibly
There are some remnants of the apophonic passive left.
Additional to the apophonic passive some verbs' stems V, VII and VIII have passive meaning

The internal or apophonic passive persists in Omani Arabic, H or B, and it is not substituted by any analytic construction or periphrasis. The only exception to this regularity , as expected, comes from the coastal cities (Lombezzi 2019:5)
